results.headline: A Faithful but Strained Adaptation
results.summary_short: “What Women Want” is a Chinese remake of the American romantic comedy that starred Mel Gibson and Helen Hunt.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What Women Want

results.headline: A Bloodless Ripoff Substitutes Sex for Suspense
results.summary_short: The film — a ripoff of Barbet Schroeder’s deliciously trashy 1992 thriller, “Single White Female” — staggers from limp beginning to lame conclusion.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Roommate

results.headline: Between the Lines of Daily Living, Connecting the Dots That Matter
results.summary_short: Siblings move in together, find a social niche, then encounter a bit of intrigue in “Cold Weather.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cold Weather

results.headline: Undying Love in the Time of Arrested Development
results.summary_short: James Keach’s new movie, “Waiting for Forever,” is a meditation on childhood extended beyond natural boundaries.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Waiting for Forever

results.headline: Plunging Into the Deep, Hoping for a Way Out
results.summary_short: In the 3-D “Sanctum,” a group of expert cavers tries to rappel, swim, climb, crawl, squeeze and swim some more where no one has gone before.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sanctum

results.headline: A Home Wrecker Faces Many Challenges, Too
results.summary_short: The title role in “The Other Woman” is played by Natalie Portman, a second wife dealing with complications in her marriage.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Other Woman

results.headline: Exploitation 101
results.summary_short: The documentary “American Grindhouse” is a textbook-style history of the seamier side of the movie business.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Grindhouse

results.headline: A Passion for Fashion
results.summary_short: “Dressed” is David Swajeski’s profile of the young clothing designer Nary Manivong.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dressed

results.headline: Humans, Who Once Buried Their Treasures, Now Bury Their Dangers
results.summary_short: “Into Eternity” is Michael Madsen’s documentary about a site being built in Finland to bury nuclear waste for 100,000 years.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Into Eternity

results.headline: Recalling the Reign of Taylor and King
results.summary_short: The documentary “Troubadors” looks at the West Hollywood nightclub that nurtured Carole King, James Taylor and other talents of the 1970s singer-songwriter movement.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Troubadours

results.headline: Jane Austen, Transmigrated To Modern-Day East L.A.
results.summary_short: “From Prada to Nada,” a retread of “Sense and Sensibility,” relies on ethnic heritage to supplant the 19th-century mores that created the tension in Jane Austen’s original story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of From Prada to Nada

results.headline: Standoff in a Frigid Circle of Hell
results.summary_short: “How I Ended This Summer,” set at an Arctic weather station, is a suspenseful man-braving-the-elements adventure and a psychological thriller.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How I Ended This Summer

results.headline: When Two Cultures Collide Under One Roof
results.summary_short: In “When We Leave,” a Turkish-German woman breaks away from her Muslim husband.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When We Leave

results.headline: Giving the Devil His Possessive Due
results.summary_short: “The Rite,” a supernatural thriller starring Anthony Hopkins as a Jesuit expert in exorcism, piles on clichés while dealing with the serious, serious business of diabolical evil.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Rite

results.headline: An Ill-Advised Love Affair
results.summary_short: “Rage (Rabia),” a film directed by Sebastián Cordero, about class conflict, is set in Spain.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rage

results.headline: Hit Man Is Back, Teaching the Tricks of the Trade
results.summary_short: A hit man takes on a protégé in this remake of the 1972 Charles Bronson film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Mechanic

results.headline: End of the World? Maybe. First, Sex.
results.summary_short: “Kaboom,” written and directed by Gregg Araki, follows libidinous college students as they look into strange doings on and off campus.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kaboom

results.headline: Extortion Gone Awry
results.summary_short: “Blackmail Boys,” a film directed by Bernard and Richard Shumanski, deals with gay themes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blackmail Boys

results.headline: An Iron Man’s Life of Might-Have-Beens
results.summary_short: “Strongman,” Zachary Levy’s lump-in-the-throat portrait of an aging muscleman, is an outsider tale of unforced rawness and lilting poignancy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Strongman

results.headline: Pushing the Limits of Endurance
results.summary_short: In “The Way Back,” the new Peter Weir film, escapees from a Siberian gulag attempt a bleak, demoralizing 4,000-mile trek to freedom in India during the early 1940s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Way Back
